97: sample_whole_space.{u_1, u_2} {Œ± : Type u_1} [PseudoMetricSpace Œ±] {Œ≤ : Type u_2} [CompactSpace Œ±] [Nonempty Œ±] [MeasurableSpace Œ±] [MeasurableSpace Œ≤] [PseudoMetricSpace Œ≤] [OpensMeasurableSpace Œ±] [BorelSpace Œ≤] (A : Algorithm Œ± Œ≤) {f : Œ± ‚Üí Œ≤} (hf : Continuous f) : Prop**Main definition**: Given a function `f`, an algorithm `A` sample the whole space if `‚àÄ Œµ > 0, lim_(n ‚Üí ‚àû) A.measure f n {u | max_min_dist u > Œµ} = 0`.

87: is_consistent.{u_1, u_2} {Œ± : Type u_1} [PseudoMetricSpace Œ±] {Œ≤ : Type u_2} [CompactSpace Œ±] [Nonempty Œ±] [PseudoMetricSpace Œ≤] [Nonempty Œ≤] [LinearOrder Œ≤] [ClosedIciTopology Œ≤] [MeasurableSpace Œ±] [MeasurableSpace Œ≤] [OpensMeasurableSpace Œ±] [BorelSpace Œ≤] (A : Algorithm Œ± Œ≤) {f : Œ± ‚Üí Œ≤} (hf : Lipschitz f) : Prop**Main definition**: An algorithm `A` is consistent over a Lipschitz function `f` if for any `Œµ > 0`, `lim_(n ‚Üí ‚àû) measure_dist_max n = 0`.

76: Algorithm.fin_measure.{u_1, u_2} {Œ± : Type u_1} {Œ≤ : Type u_2} [MeasurableSpace Œ±] [TopologicalSpace Œ±] [OpensMeasurableSpace Œ±] [MeasurableSpace Œ≤] [TopologicalSpace Œ≤] [BorelSpace Œ≤] (A : Algorithm Œ± Œ≤) {f : Œ± ‚Üí Œ≤} (hf : Continuous f) {n : ‚Ñï} : MeasureTheory.Measure (iter Œ± n)The measure on finite sequences of iterations, defined by pushing forward `measure` along the measurable function `frestrictLe n : (‚Ñï ‚Üí Œ±) ‚Üí iter Œ± n` that restricts the infinite sequence to its first `n` elements. This is the measure that will be used throughout the formalization.
75: Eq.{u_1} {Œ± : Sort u_1} : Œ± ‚Üí Œ± ‚Üí PropThe equality relation. It has one introduction rule, `Eq.refl`. We use `a = b` as notation for `Eq a b`. A fundamental property of equality is that it is an equivalence relation. ``` variable (Œ± : Type) (a b c d : Œ±) variable (hab : a = b) (hcb : c = b) (hcd : c = d) example : a = d := Eq.trans (Eq.trans hab (Eq.symm hcb)) hcd ``` Equality is much more than an equivalence relation, however. It has the important property that every assertion respects the equivalence, in the sense that we can substitute equal expressions without changing the truth value. That is, given `h1 : a = b` and `h2 : p a`, we can construct a proof for `p b` using substitution: `Eq.subst h1 h2`. Example: ``` example (Œ± : Type) (a b : Œ±) (p : Œ± ‚Üí Prop) (h1 : a = b) (h2 : p a) : p b := Eq.subst h1 h2 example (Œ± : Type) (a b : Œ±) (p : Œ± ‚Üí Prop) (h1 : a = b) (h2 : p a) : p b := h1 ‚ñ∏ h2 ``` The triangle in the second presentation is a macro built on top of `Eq.subst` and `Eq.symm`, and you can enter it by typing `\t`. For more information: [Equality](https://lean-lang.org/theorem_proving_in_lean4/quantifiers_and_equality.html#equality) Conventions for notations in identifiers: * The recommended spelling of `=` in identifiers is `eq`.
73: Finset.Iic.{u_1} {Œ± : Type u_1} [Preorder Œ±] [LocallyFiniteOrderBot Œ±] (b : Œ±) : Finset Œ±The finset $(-‚àû, b]$ of elements `x` such that `x ‚â§ b`. Basically `Set.Iic b` as a finset.
72: Set.pi.{u_1, u_2} {Œπ : Type u_1} {Œ± : Œπ ‚Üí Type u_2} (s : Set Œπ) (t : (i : Œπ) ‚Üí Set (Œ± i)) : Set ((i : Œπ) ‚Üí Œ± i)Given an index set `Œπ` and a family of sets `t : Œ† i, Set (Œ± i)`, `pi s t` is the set of dependent functions `f : Œ†a, œÄ a` such that `f i` belongs to `t i` whenever `i ‚àà s`.
71: Set.univ.{u} {Œ± : Type u} : Set Œ±The universal set on a type `Œ±` is the set containing all elements of `Œ±`. This is conceptually the "same as" `Œ±` (in set theory, it is actually the same), but type theory makes the distinction that `Œ±` is a type while `Set.univ` is a term of type `Set Œ±`. `Set.univ` can itself be coerced to a type `‚Ü•Set.univ` which is in bijection with (but distinct from) `Œ±`.
70: MeasureTheory.Measure.restrict.{u_2} {Œ± : Type u_2} {_m0 : MeasurableSpace Œ±} (Œº : Measure Œ±) (s : Set Œ±) : Measure Œ±Restrict a measure `Œº` to a set `s`.

69: Set.EqOn.{u, v} {Œ± : Type u} {Œ≤ : Type v} (f‚ÇÅ f‚ÇÇ : Œ± ‚Üí Œ≤) (s : Set Œ±) : PropTwo functions `f‚ÇÅ f‚ÇÇ : Œ± ‚Üí Œ≤` are equal on `s` if `f‚ÇÅ x = f‚ÇÇ x` for all `x ‚àà s`.
65: Algorithm.eq_restrict.{u_1, u_2} {Œ± : Type u_1} {Œ≤ : Type u_2} [MeasurableSpace Œ±] [TopologicalSpace Œ±] [OpensMeasurableSpace Œ±] [MeasurableSpace Œ≤] [TopologicalSpace Œ≤] [BorelSpace Œ≤] (A : Algorithm Œ± Œ≤) {f g : Œ± ‚Üí Œ≤} (hf : Continuous f) (hg : Continuous g) {s : Set Œ±} (hs : MeasurableSet s) (h : EqOn f g s) (n : ‚Ñï) : (A.fin_measure hf).restrict (univ.pi fun x => s) = (A.fin_measure hg).restrict (univ.pi fun x => s)If two continuous functions `f` and `g` agree on a measurable set `s`, then the algorithm's induced measures at iteration `n` are identical when restricted to trajectories that stay within `s`. This establishes that the algorithm depends only on the objective function values on the relevant domain.
64: Membership.mem.{u, v} {Œ± : outParam (Type u)} {Œ≥ : Type v} [self : Membership Œ± Œ≥] : Œ≥ ‚Üí Œ± ‚Üí PropThe membership relation `a ‚àà s : Prop` where `a : Œ±`, `s : Œ≥`. Conventions for notations in identifiers: * The recommended spelling of `‚àà` in identifiers is `mem`.

61: LE.le.{u} {Œ± : Type u} [self : LE Œ±] : Œ± ‚Üí Œ± ‚Üí PropThe less-equal relation: `x ‚â§ y` Conventions for notations in identifiers: * The recommended spelling of `‚â§` in identifiers is `le`. * The recommended spelling of `<=` in identifiers is `le` (prefer `‚â§` over `<=`).
60: Nat : TypeThe natural numbers, starting at zero. This type is special-cased by both the kernel and the compiler, and overridden with an efficient implementation. Both use a fast arbitrary-precision arithmetic library (usually [GMP](https://gmplib.org/)); at runtime, `Nat` values that are sufficiently small are unboxed.
6: MeasureTheory.Measure.{u_6} (Œ± : Type u_6) [MeasurableSpace Œ±] : Type u_6A measure is defined to be an outer measure that is countably additive on measurable sets, with the additional assumption that the outer measure is the canonical extension of the restricted measure. The measure of a set `s`, denoted `Œº s`, is an extended nonnegative real. The real-valued version is written `Œº.real s`.
59: Tuple.subTuple.{u_1} {Œ± : Type u_1} {n m : ‚Ñï} (hnm : n ‚â§ m) (u : iter Œ± m) : iter Œ± nGiven `n ‚â§ m`, this is the restriction of a function `u : iter Œ± m` to a function `iter Œ± n`.
53: MeasurableSet.{u_1} {Œ± : Type u_1} [MeasurableSpace Œ±] (s : Set Œ±) : Prop`MeasurableSet s` means that `s` is measurable (in the ambient measure space on `Œ±`)
51: Set.{u} (Œ± : Type u) : Type uA set is a collection of elements of some type `Œ±`. Although `Set` is defined as `Œ± ‚Üí Prop`, this is an implementation detail which should not be relied on. Instead, `setOf` and membership of a set (`‚àà`) should be used to convert between sets and predicates.
5: Algorithm.ŒΩ.{u_1, u_2} {Œ± : Type u_1} {Œ≤ : Type u_2} [MeasurableSpace Œ±] [MeasurableSpace Œ≤] (self : Algorithm Œ± Œ≤) : Measure Œ±
49: Algorithm.fin_measure_mono.{u_1, u_2} {Œ± : Type u_1} {Œ≤ : Type u_2} [MeasurableSpace Œ±] [TopologicalSpace Œ±] [OpensMeasurableSpace Œ±] [MeasurableSpace Œ≤] [TopologicalSpace Œ≤] [BorelSpace Œ≤] (A : Algorithm Œ± Œ≤) {n m : ‚Ñï} {s : Set (iter Œ± n)} (hs : MeasurableSet s) {e : Set (iter Œ± m)} (he : MeasurableSet e) (hmn : n ‚â§ m) (hse : e ‚äÜ {u | subTuple hmn u ‚àà s}) {f : Œ± ‚Üí Œ≤} (hf : Continuous f) : (A.fin_measure hf) e ‚â§ (A.fin_measure hf) sMonotonicity of the algorithm's induced measures under trajectory extension. Let `s : Set iter Œ± n` be a measurable set of point sequences of length `n`, and `e : Set iter Œ± m` for some `m ‚â• n` a set of longer trajectories such that every `u ‚àà e` satisfies `subTuple hmn u ‚àà s`. Then the measure assigned to `e` by the algorithm at step `m` is less than or equal to the measure assigned to `s` at step `n`. This expresses that the family of measures is projectively consistent: the measure on longer trajectories contracts to the measure on shorter ones via truncation. Formally: if `e ‚äÜ {u | subTuple hmn u ‚àà s}`, then `A.fin_measure hf m e ‚â§ A.fin_measure hf n s`.
48: Preorder.frestrictLe.{u_1, u_2} {Œ± : Type u_1} [Preorder Œ±] {œÄ : Œ± ‚Üí Type u_2} [LocallyFiniteOrderBot Œ±] (a : Œ±) (f : (i : Œ±) ‚Üí œÄ i) (i : ‚Ü•(Finset.Iic a)) : œÄ ‚ÜëiRestrict domain of a function `f` indexed by `Œ±` to elements `‚â§ a`, seen as a finite set.
47: MeasureTheory.Measure.map.{u_4, u_5} {Œ± : Type u_4} {Œ≤ : Type u_5} [MeasurableSpace Œ±] [MeasurableSpace Œ≤] (f : Œ± ‚Üí Œ≤) (Œº : Measure Œ±) : Measure Œ≤The pushforward of a measure. It is defined to be `0` if `f` is not an almost everywhere measurable function.
46: Algorithm.fin_measure.{u_1, u_2} {Œ± : Type u_1} {Œ≤ : Type u_2} [MeasurableSpace Œ±] [TopologicalSpace Œ±] [OpensMeasurableSpace Œ±] [MeasurableSpace Œ≤] [TopologicalSpace Œ≤] [BorelSpace Œ≤] (A : Algorithm Œ± Œ≤) {f : Œ± ‚Üí Œ≤} (hf : Continuous f) {n : ‚Ñï} : Measure (iter Œ± n)The measure on finite sequences of iterations, defined by pushing forward `measure` along the measurable function `frestrictLe n : (‚Ñï ‚Üí Œ±) ‚Üí iter Œ± n` that restricts the infinite sequence to its first `n` elements. This is the measure that will be used throughout the formalization.
45: `infer_instance` is an abbreviation for `exact inferInstance`. It synthesizes a value of any target type by typeclass inference.
44: The `simp` tactic uses lemmas and hypotheses to simplify the main goal target or non-dependent hypotheses. It has many variants: - `simp` simplifies the main goal target using lemmas tagged with the attribute `[simp]`. - `simp [h‚ÇÅ, h‚ÇÇ, ..., h‚Çô]` simplifies the main goal target using the lemmas tagged with the attribute `[simp]` and the given `h·µ¢`'s, where the `h·µ¢`'s are expressions.- - If an `h·µ¢` is a defined constant `f`, then `f` is unfolded. If `f` has equational lemmas associated with it (and is not a projection or a `reducible` definition), these are used to rewrite with `f`. - `simp [*]` simplifies the main goal target using the lemmas tagged with the attribute `[simp]` and all hypotheses. - `simp only [h‚ÇÅ, h‚ÇÇ, ..., h‚Çô]` is like `simp [h‚ÇÅ, h‚ÇÇ, ..., h‚Çô]` but does not use `[simp]` lemmas. - `simp [-id‚ÇÅ, ..., -id‚Çô]` simplifies the main goal target using the lemmas tagged with the attribute `[simp]`, but removes the ones named `id·µ¢`. - `simp at h‚ÇÅ h‚ÇÇ ... h‚Çô` simplifies the hypotheses `h‚ÇÅ : T‚ÇÅ` ... `h‚Çô : T‚Çô`. If the target or another hypothesis depends on `h·µ¢`, a new simplified hypothesis `h·µ¢` is introduced, but the old one remains in the local context. - `simp at *` simplifies all the hypotheses and the target. - `simp [*] at *` simplifies target and all (propositional) hypotheses using the other hypotheses.
43: Continuous.{u, v} {X : Type u} {Y : Type v} [TopologicalSpace X] [TopologicalSpace Y] (f : X ‚Üí Y) : PropA function between topological spaces is continuous if the preimage of every open set is open. Registered as a structure to make sure it is not unfolded by Lean.
42: BorelSpace.{u_6} (Œ± : Type u_6) [TopologicalSpace Œ±] [MeasurableSpace Œ±] : PropA space with `MeasurableSpace` and `TopologicalSpace` structures such that the `œÉ`-algebra of measurable sets is exactly the `œÉ`-algebra generated by open sets.
4: MeasurableSpace.{u_7} (Œ± : Type u_7) : Type u_7A measurable space is a space equipped with a œÉ-algebra.
38: OpensMeasurableSpace.{u_6} (Œ± : Type u_6) [TopologicalSpace Œ±] [h : MeasurableSpace Œ±] : PropA space with `MeasurableSpace` and `TopologicalSpace` structures such that all open sets are measurable.
36: TopologicalSpace.{u} (X : Type u) : Type uA topology on `X`.
33: A type universe. `Type ‚â° Type 0`, `Type u ‚â° Sort (u + 1)`.
32: `by tac` constructs a term of the expected type by running the tactic(s) `tac`.
31: ProbabilityTheory.Kernel.avg.{u_1, u_2} {Œ± : Type u_1} {Œ≤ : Type u_2} [MeasurableSpace Œ±] [MeasurableSpace Œ≤] (Œ∫ : Kernel Œ± Œ≤) (Œº : Measure Œ±) : Measure Œ≤The average of a kernel `Œ∫` by a measure `Œº`. Defined as `s‚Ü¶ ‚à´‚Åª a, Œ∫ a s ‚àÇŒº`
30: Algorithm.measure.{u_1, u_2} {Œ± : Type u_1} {Œ≤ : Type u_2} [MeasurableSpace Œ±] [TopologicalSpace Œ±] [OpensMeasurableSpace Œ±] [MeasurableSpace Œ≤] [TopologicalSpace Œ≤] [BorelSpace Œ≤] {f : Œ± ‚Üí Œ≤} (hf : Continuous f) (A : Algorithm Œ± Œ≤) : Measure (‚Ñï ‚Üí Œ±)The measure on infinite sequences of iterations. It is constructed by first obtaining a kernel from `iter Œ± 0` to `‚Ñï ‚Üí Œ±` via the Ionescu-Tulcea theorem, and then averaging the kernel over the initial measure `A.ŒΩ_mequiv`. This gives a measure on the space of infinite sequences of points in `Œ±`, which can be used to analyze the convergence properties of the algorithm.
3: The syntax `variable (X Y ... Z : Type*)` creates a new distinct implicit universe variable `> 0` for each variable in the sequence.
29: MeasurableEquiv.funUnique.{u_8, u_9} (Œ± : Type u_8) (Œ≤ : Type u_9) [Unique Œ±] [MeasurableSpace Œ≤] : (Œ± ‚Üí Œ≤) ‚âÉ·µê Œ≤If `Œ±` has a unique term, then the type of function `Œ± ‚Üí Œ≤` is measurably equivalent to `Œ≤`.
28: MeasureTheory.Measure.comap.{u_1, u_2} {Œ± : Type u_1} {Œ≤ : Type u_2} [MeasurableSpace Œ±] [MeasurableSpace Œ≤] (f : Œ± ‚Üí Œ≤) (Œº : Measure Œ≤) : Measure Œ±Pullback of a `Measure`. If `f` sends each measurable set to a null-measurable set, then for each measurable set `s` we have `comap f Œº s = Œº (f '' s)`. Note that if `f` is not injective, this definition assigns `Set.univ` measure zero.
27: Algorithm.ŒΩ_mequiv.{u_1, u_2} {Œ± : Type u_1} {Œ≤ : Type u_2} [MeasurableSpace Œ±] [MeasurableSpace Œ≤] (A : Algorithm Œ± Œ≤) : Measure (iter Œ± 0)The measure `ŒΩ` that has been pulled back along the measurable equivalence `MeasurableEquiv.funUnique (iter Œ± 0) Œ±` to change the type of `ŒΩ` from `Measure Œ±` to `Measure (iter Œ± 0)`.
26: Continuous.measurable.{u_1, u_3} {Œ± : Type u_1} {Œ≥ : Type u_3} [TopologicalSpace Œ±] [MeasurableSpace Œ±] [OpensMeasurableSpace Œ±] [TopologicalSpace Œ≥] [MeasurableSpace Œ≥] [BorelSpace Œ≥] {f : Œ± ‚Üí Œ≥} (hf : Continuous f) : Measurable fA continuous function from an `OpensMeasurableSpace` to a `BorelSpace` is measurable.

22: Tuple.prod_eval.{u_1, u_2} {Œ± : Type u_1} {Œ≤ : Type u_2} (n : ‚Ñï) (f : Œ± ‚Üí Œ≤) (u : iter Œ± n) : iter Œ± n √ó (‚Ü•(Finset.Iic n) ‚Üí Œ≤)Given `n`, a function `f : Œ± ‚Üí Œ≤` and a function `u : iter Œ± n`, this is the pair `(u, f ‚àò u)`, where `f ‚àò u` is the function from `Fin (n + 1)` to `Œ≤` that applies `f` to the values of `u`.
21: ProbabilityTheory.Kernel.comap.{u_1, u_2, u_4} {Œ± : Type u_1} {Œ≤ : Type u_2} {mŒ± : MeasurableSpace Œ±} {mŒ≤ : MeasurableSpace Œ≤} {Œ≥ : Type u_4} {mŒ≥ : MeasurableSpace Œ≥} (Œ∫ : Kernel Œ± Œ≤) (g : Œ≥ ‚Üí Œ±) (hg : Measurable g) : Kernel Œ≥ Œ≤Pullback of a kernel, such that for each set s `comap Œ∫ g hg c s = Œ∫ (g c) s`. We include measurability in the assumptions instead of using junk values to make sure that typeclass inference can infer that the `comap` of a Markov kernel is again a Markov kernel.
19: iter.{u_1} (Œ± : Type u_1) (n : ‚Ñï) : Type u_1`iter Œ± n` is the type of finite sequences of elements in `Œ±` of length `n + 1`. It represents the history of `n + 1` steps in an iterative process, with entries indexed by `Fin (n + 1)` (i.e., from `0` to `n`). Used in the context of stochastic iterative algorithms to store past evaluations or points.
18: Algorithm.iter_comap.{u_1, u_2} {Œ± : Type u_1} {Œ≤ : Type u_2} [MeasurableSpace Œ±] [TopologicalSpace Œ±] [OpensMeasurableSpace Œ±] [MeasurableSpace Œ≤] [TopologicalSpace Œ≤] [BorelSpace Œ≤] (A : Algorithm Œ± Œ≤) {f : Œ± ‚Üí Œ≤} (hf : Continuous f) (n : ‚Ñï) : Kernel (iter Œ± n) Œ±Given a continuous function `f : Œ± ‚Üí Œ≤` representing the evaluation (e.g., objective function), this constructs a new kernel that maps a history of points (in `iter Œ± n`) to a probability distribution over the next point in `Œ±`. The original algorithm `A` provides a transition kernel `A.kernel_iter n` that depends on both the previously proposed points and their corresponding evaluations. However, in practice, the algorithm itself only generates the sequence of points, and the evaluations are computed externally by applying `f` to each point. The function `prod_eval n f` deterministically reconstructs the full history (points and their evaluations) from the point sequence alone, using `f` and the `comap` pulls back the original kernel along this map, resulting in a kernel that operates directly on the sequence of points.
17: ProbabilityTheory.Kernel.traj.{u_1} {X : ‚Ñï ‚Üí Type u_1} [(n : ‚Ñï) ‚Üí MeasurableSpace (X n)] (Œ∫ : (n : ‚Ñï) ‚Üí Kernel ((i : ‚Ü•(Finset.Iic n)) ‚Üí X ‚Üëi) (X (n + 1))) [‚àÄ (n : ‚Ñï), IsMarkovKernel (Œ∫ n)] (a : ‚Ñï) : Kernel ((i : ‚Ü•(Finset.Iic a)) ‚Üí X ‚Üëi) ((n : ‚Ñï) ‚Üí X n)*Ionescu-Tulcea Theorem* : Given a family of kernels `Œ∫ n` taking variables in `Iic n` with value in `X (n + 1)`, the kernel `traj Œ∫ a` takes a variable `x` depending on the variables `i ‚â§ a` and associates to it a kernel on trajectories depending on all variables, where the entries with index `‚â§ a` are those of `x`, and then one follows iteratively the kernels `Œ∫ a`, then `Œ∫ (a + 1)`, and so on. The fact that such a kernel exists on infinite trajectories is not obvious, and is the content of the Ionescu-Tulcea theorem.
159: `linarith` attempts to find a contradiction between hypotheses that are linear (in)equalities. Equivalently, it can prove a linear inequality by assuming its negation and proving `False`. In theory, `linarith` should prove any goal that is true in the theory of linear arithmetic over the rationals. While there is some special handling for non-dense orders like `Nat` and `Int`, this tactic is not complete for these theories and will not prove every true goal. It will solve goals over arbitrary types that instantiate `CommRing`, `LinearOrder` and `IsStrictOrderedRing`. An example: ```lean example (x y z : ‚Ñö) (h1 : 2*x < 3*y) (h2 : -4*x + 2*z < 0) (h3 : 12*y - 4* z < 0) : False := by linarith ``` `linarith` will use all appropriate hypotheses and the negation of the goal, if applicable. Disequality hypotheses require case splitting and are not normally considered (see the `splitNe` option below). `linarith [t1, t2, t3]` will additionally use proof terms `t1, t2, t3`. `linarith only [h1, h2, h3, t1, t2, t3]` will use only the goal (if relevant), local hypotheses `h1`, `h2`, `h3`, and proofs `t1`, `t2`, `t3`. It will ignore the rest of the local context. `linarith!` will use a stronger reducibility setting to try to identify atoms. For example, ```lean example (x : ‚Ñö) : id x ‚â• x := by linarith ``` will fail, because `linarith` will not identify `x` and `id x`. `linarith!` will. This can sometimes be expensive. `linarith (config := { .. })` takes a config object with five optional arguments: * `discharger` specifies a tactic to be used for reducing an algebraic equation in the proof stage. The default is `ring`. Other options include `simp` for basic problems. * `transparency` controls how hard `linarith` will try to match atoms to each other. By default it will only unfold `reducible` definitions. * If `splitHypotheses` is true, `linarith` will split conjunctions in the context into separate hypotheses. * If `splitNe` is `true`, `linarith` will case split on disequality hypotheses. For a given `x ‚â† y` hypothesis, `linarith` is run with both `x < y` and `x > y`, and so this runs linarith exponentially many times with respect to the number of disequality hypotheses. (`false` by default.) * If `exfalso` is `false`, `linarith` will fail when the goal is neither an inequality nor `False`. (`true` by default.) * `restrict_type` (not yet implemented in mathlib4) will only use hypotheses that are inequalities over `tp`. This is useful if you have e.g. both integer- and rational-valued inequalities in the local context, which can sometimes confuse the tactic. A variant, `nlinarith`, does some basic preprocessing to handle some nonlinear goals. The option `set_option trace.linarith true` will trace certain intermediate stages of the `linarith` routine.
156: Lipschitz.f_tilde_apply_out.{u_1} {Œ± : Type u_1} [NormedAddCommGroup Œ±] [CompactSpace Œ±] [Nonempty Œ±] {f : Œ± ‚Üí ‚Ñù} (hf : Lipschitz f) (c : Œ±) {Œµ : ‚Ñù} {x : Œ±} (hx : x ‚àâ ball c (Œµ / 2)) : hf.f_tilde c Œµ x = f x
155: The `have` tactic is for adding opaque definitions and hypotheses to the local context of the main goal. The definitions forget their associated value and cannot be unfolded, unlike definitions added by the `let` tactic. * `have h : t := e` adds the hypothesis `h : t` if `e` is a term of type `t`. * `have h := e` uses the type of `e` for `t`. * `have : t := e` and `have := e` use `this` for the name of the hypothesis. * `have pat := e` for a pattern `pat` is equivalent to `match e with | pat => _`, where `_` stands for the tactics that follow this one. It is convenient for types that have only one applicable constructor. For example, given `h : p ‚àß q ‚àß r`, `have ‚ü®h‚ÇÅ, h‚ÇÇ, h‚ÇÉ‚ü© := h` produces the hypotheses `h‚ÇÅ : p`, `h‚ÇÇ : q`, and `h‚ÇÉ : r`. * The syntax `have (eq := h) pat := e` is equivalent to `match h : e with | pat => _`, which adds the equation `h : e = pat` to the local context. The tactic supports all the same syntax variants and options as the `have` term. ## Properties and relations * It is not possible to unfold a variable introduced using `have`, since the definition's value is forgotten. The `let` tactic introduces definitions that can be unfolded. * The `have h : t := e` is like doing `let h : t := e; clear_value h`. * The `have` tactic is preferred for propositions, and `let` is preferred for non-propositions. * Sometimes `have` is used for non-propositions to ensure that the variable is never unfolded, which may be important for performance reasons. Consider using the equivalent `let +nondep` to indicate the intent.
154: False : Prop`False` is the empty proposition. Thus, it has no introduction rules. It represents a contradiction. `False` elimination rule, `False.rec`, expresses the fact that anything follows from a contradiction. This rule is sometimes called ex falso (short for ex falso sequitur quodlibet), or the principle of explosion. For more information: [Propositional Logic](https://lean-lang.org/theorem_proving_in_lean4/propositions_and_proofs.html#propositional-logic)
152: `by_contra h` proves `‚ä¢ p` by contradiction, introducing a hypothesis `h : ¬¨p` and proving `False`. * If `p` is a negation `¬¨q`, `h : q` will be introduced instead of `¬¨¬¨q`. * If `p` is decidable, it uses `Decidable.byContradiction` instead of `Classical.byContradiction`. * If `h` is omitted, the introduced variable `_: ¬¨p` will be anonymous.

132: `exact e` closes the main goal if its target type matches that of `e`.
131: Tactic for evaluating expressions in *commutative* (semi)rings, allowing for variables in the exponent. If the goal is not appropriate for `ring` (e.g. not an equality) `ring_nf` will be suggested. * `ring!` will use a more aggressive reducibility setting to determine equality of atoms. * `ring1` fails if the target is not an equality. For example: ``` example (n : ‚Ñï) (m : ‚Ñ§) : 2^(n+1) * m = 2 * 2^n * m := by ring example (a b : ‚Ñ§) (n : ‚Ñï) : (a + b)^(n + 2) = (a^2 + b^2 + a * b + b * a) * (a + b)^n := by ring example (x y : ‚Ñï) : x + id y = y + id x := by ring! example (x : ‚Ñï) (h : x * 2 > 5): x + x > 5 := by ring; assumption -- suggests ring_nf ```
13: prod_iter_image.{u_1, u_2} (Œ± : Type u_1) (Œ≤ : Type u_2) (n : ‚Ñï) : Type (max u_1 u_2)`prod_iter_image Œ± Œ≤ n` is the input space of the algorithm at iteration `n`. It consists of: - a sequence of `n + 1` past points in `Œ±`, - and their corresponding evaluations in `Œ≤`. This pair encodes the full information available up to iteration `n`.
128: Given a main goal `ctx ‚ä¢ t`, `suffices h : t' from e` replaces the main goal with `ctx ‚ä¢ t'`, `e` must have type `t` in the context `ctx, h : t'`. The variant `suffices h : t' by tac` is a shorthand for `suffices h : t' from by tac`. If `h :` is omitted, the name `this` is used.
127: `rw` is like `rewrite`, but also tries to close the goal by "cheap" (reducible) `rfl` afterwards.
125: Introduces one or more hypotheses, optionally naming and/or pattern-matching them. For each hypothesis to be introduced, the remaining main goal's target type must be a `let` or function type. * `intro` by itself introduces one anonymous hypothesis, which can be accessed by e.g. `assumption`. It is equivalent to `intro _`. * `intro x y` introduces two hypotheses and names them. Individual hypotheses can be anonymized via `_`, given a type ascription, or matched against a pattern: ```lean -- ... ‚ä¢ Œ± √ó Œ≤ ‚Üí ... intro (a, b) -- ..., a : Œ±, b : Œ≤ ‚ä¢ ... ``` * `intro rfl` is short for `intro h; subst h`, if `h` is an equality where the left-hand or right-hand side is a variable. * Alternatively, `intro` can be combined with pattern matching much like `fun`: ```lean intro | n + 1, 0 => tac | ... ```
124: HAdd.hAdd.{u, v, w} {Œ± : Type u} {Œ≤ : Type v} {Œ≥ : outParam (Type w)} [self : HAdd Œ± Œ≤ Œ≥] : Œ± ‚Üí Œ≤ ‚Üí Œ≥`a + b` computes the sum of `a` and `b`. The meaning of this notation is type-dependent. Conventions for notations in identifiers: * The recommended spelling of `+` in identifiers is `add`.
123: HSub.hSub.{u, v, w} {Œ± : Type u} {Œ≤ : Type v} {Œ≥ : outParam (Type w)} [self : HSub Œ± Œ≤ Œ≥] : Œ± ‚Üí Œ≤ ‚Üí Œ≥`a - b` computes the difference of `a` and `b`. The meaning of this notation is type-dependent. * For natural numbers, this operator saturates at 0: `a - b = 0` when `a ‚â§ b`. Conventions for notations in identifiers: * The recommended spelling of `-` in identifiers is `sub` (when used as a binary operator).
122: HMul.hMul.{u, v, w} {Œ± : Type u} {Œ≤ : Type v} {Œ≥ : outParam (Type w)} [self : HMul Œ± Œ≤ Œ≥] : Œ± ‚Üí Œ≤ ‚Üí Œ≥`a * b` computes the product of `a` and `b`. The meaning of this notation is type-dependent. Conventions for notations in identifiers: * The recommended spelling of `*` in identifiers is `mul`.
121: HDiv.hDiv.{u, v, w} {Œ± : Type u} {Œ≤ : Type v} {Œ≥ : outParam (Type w)} [self : HDiv Œ± Œ≤ Œ≥] : Œ± ‚Üí Œ≤ ‚Üí Œ≥`a / b` computes the result of dividing `a` by `b`. The meaning of this notation is type-dependent. * For most types like `Nat`, `Int`, `Rat`, `Real`, `a / 0` is defined to be `0`. * For `Nat`, `a / b` rounds downwards. * For `Int`, `a / b` rounds downwards if `b` is positive or upwards if `b` is negative. It is implemented as `Int.ediv`, the unique function satisfying `a % b + b * (a / b) = a` and `0 ‚â§ a % b < natAbs b` for `b ‚â† 0`. Other rounding conventions are available using the functions `Int.fdiv` (floor rounding) and `Int.tdiv` (truncation rounding). * For `Float`, `a / 0` follows the IEEE 754 semantics for division, usually resulting in `inf` or `nan`. Conventions for notations in identifiers: * The recommended spelling of `/` in identifiers is `div`.
120: Metric.sphere.{u} {Œ± : Type u} [PseudoMetricSpace Œ±] (x : Œ±) (Œµ : ‚Ñù) : Set Œ±`sphere x Œµ` is the set of all points `y` with `dist y x = Œµ`
12: ProbabilityTheory.Kernel.{u_1, u_2} (Œ± : Type u_1) (Œ≤ : Type u_2) [MeasurableSpace Œ±] [MeasurableSpace Œ≤] : Type (max u_1 u_2)A kernel from a measurable space `Œ±` to another measurable space `Œ≤` is a measurable function `Œ∫ : Œ± ‚Üí Measure Œ≤`. The measurable space structure on `MeasureTheory.Measure Œ≤` is given by `MeasureTheory.Measure.instMeasurableSpace`. A map `Œ∫ : Œ± ‚Üí MeasureTheory.Measure Œ≤` is measurable iff `‚àÄ s : Set Œ≤, MeasurableSet s ‚Üí Measurable (fun a ‚Ü¶ Œ∫ a s)`.
119: Lipschitz.if.{u_1} {Œ± : Type u_1} [NormedAddCommGroup Œ±] [NormedSpace ‚Ñù Œ±] {f g : Œ± ‚Üí ‚Ñù} {c : Œ±} {Œµ : ‚Ñù} [(a : Œ±) ‚Üí Decidable (a ‚àà ball c Œµ)] (hp : ‚àÄ a ‚àà sphere c Œµ, g a = 0) (hf : Lipschitz f) (hg : Lipschitz g) : Lipschitz fun a => if a ‚àà ball c Œµ then f a + g a else f a
118: `refine e` behaves like `exact e`, except that named (`?x`) or unnamed (`?_`) holes in `e` that are not solved by unification with the main goal's target type are converted into new goals, using the hole's name, if any, as the goal case name.
117: LT.lt.{u} {Œ± : Type u} [self : LT Œ±] : Œ± ‚Üí Œ± ‚Üí PropThe less-than relation: `x < y` Conventions for notations in identifiers: * The recommended spelling of `<` in identifiers is `lt`.
115: Lipschitz.f_tilde_lipschitz.{u_1} {Œ± : Type u_1} [NormedAddCommGroup Œ±] [CompactSpace Œ±] [Nonempty Œ±] {f : Œ± ‚Üí ‚Ñù} (hf : Lipschitz f) (c : Œ±) [NormedSpace ‚Ñù Œ±] {Œµ : ‚Ñù} (Œµ_pos : 0 < Œµ) : Lipschitz (hf.f_tilde c Œµ)

113: Metric.ball.{u} {Œ± : Type u} [PseudoMetricSpace Œ±] (x : Œ±) (Œµ : ‚Ñù) : Set Œ±`ball x Œµ` is the set of all points `y` with `dist y x < Œµ`
112: `if c then t else e` is notation for `ite c t e`, "if-then-else", which decides to return `t` or `e` depending on whether `c` is true or false. The explicit argument `c : Prop` does not have any actual computational content, but there is an additional `[Decidable c]` argument synthesized by typeclass inference which actually determines how to evaluate `c` to true or false. Write `if h : c then t else e` instead for a "dependent if-then-else" `dite`, which allows `t`/`e` to use the fact that `c` is true/false.
111: Lipschitz.f_tilde.{u_1} {Œ± : Type u_1} [NormedAddCommGroup Œ±] [CompactSpace Œ±] [Nonempty Œ±] {f : Œ± ‚Üí ‚Ñù} (hf : Lipschitz f) (c : Œ±) (Œµ : ‚Ñù) (x : Œ±) : ‚ÑùGiven a `Lipschitz` function `f` over a `CompactSpace Œ±`, construct a `Lipschitz` function (see `Lipschitz.f_tilde_lipschitz`) that is indistinguishable from `f` outside of a ball of radius `Œµ` such that the maximum of this new function is greater than the maximum of `f` and is located in the ball.
110: Iff (a b : Prop) : PropIf and only if, or logical bi-implication. `a ‚Üî b` means that `a` implies `b` and vice versa. By `propext`, this implies that `a` and `b` are equal and hence any expression involving `a` is equivalent to the corresponding expression with `b` instead. Conventions for notations in identifiers: * The recommended spelling of `‚Üî` in identifiers is `iff`. * The recommended spelling of `<->` in identifiers is `iff` (prefer `‚Üî` over `<->`).
109: Nonempty.{u} (Œ± : Sort u) : Prop`Nonempty Œ±` is a typeclass that says that `Œ±` is not an empty type, that is, there exists an element in the type. It differs from `Inhabited Œ±` in that `Nonempty Œ±` is a `Prop`, which means that it does not actually carry an element of `Œ±`, only a proof that *there exists* such an element. Given `Nonempty Œ±`, you can construct an element of `Œ±` *nonconstructively* using `Classical.choice`.
107: CompactSpace.{u_1} (X : Type u_1) [TopologicalSpace X] : PropType class for compact spaces. Separation is sometimes included in the definition, especially in the French literature, but we do not include it here.
105: Real : TypeThe type `‚Ñù` of real numbers constructed as equivalence classes of Cauchy sequences of rational numbers.
104: NormedSpace.{u_6, u_7} (ùïú : Type u_6) (E : Type u_7) [NormedField ùïú] [SeminormedAddCommGroup E] : Type (max u_6 u_7)A normed space over a normed field is a vector space endowed with a norm which satisfies the equality `‚Äñc ‚Ä¢ x‚Äñ = ‚Äñc‚Äñ ‚Äñx‚Äñ`. We require only `‚Äñc ‚Ä¢ x‚Äñ ‚â§ ‚Äñc‚Äñ ‚Äñx‚Äñ` in the definition, then prove `‚Äñc ‚Ä¢ x‚Äñ = ‚Äñc‚Äñ ‚Äñx‚Äñ` in `norm_smul`. Note that since this requires `SeminormedAddCommGroup` and not `NormedAddCommGroup`, this typeclass can be used for "semi normed spaces" too, just as `Module` can be used for "semi modules".
102: NormedAddCommGroup.{u_8} (E : Type u_8) : Type u_8A normed group is an additive group endowed with a norm for which `dist x y = ‚Äñx - y‚Äñ` defines a metric space structure.
10: Algorithm.kernel_iter.{u_1, u_2} {Œ± : Type u_1} {Œ≤ : Type u_2} [MeasurableSpace Œ±] [MeasurableSpace Œ≤] (self : Algorithm Œ± Œ≤) (n : ‚Ñï) : Kernel (prod_iter_image Œ± Œ≤ n) Œ±
0: Algorithm.{u_1, u_2} (Œ± : Type u_1) (Œ≤ : Type u_2) [MeasurableSpace Œ±] [MeasurableSpace Œ≤] : Type (max u_1 u_2)`Algorithm Œ± Œ≤` represents a general iterative stochastic optimization algorithm. It models a sequence of updates where: - `Œ±` is the search space (e.g., parameters, candidate solutions), - `Œ≤` is the evaluation space (e.g., objective values, feedback), - `ŒΩ` is the initial probability measure over `Œ±` (the starting distribution of candidates), - `kernel_iter n` is a Markov kernel that outputs a new candidate in `Œ±` given the history of the first `n` points and their evaluations, i.e., from the space `prod_iter_image Œ± Œ≤ n` = (`Œ± √ó Œ≤`)‚Åø, - `markov_kernel n` asserts that each such `kernel_iter n` is a valid Markov kernel.
